text: a high-tech eye for British skies the
Army's new unmanned spy plane will be
deployed around the world but most of
the time it'll be based in and fly over
Wiltshire we're about to deliver into
service the Watchkeeper unmanned
aircraft system which is the first
unmanned aircraft system that will be
certified for flying in UK airspace in a
wide range of contingent situations and
and and it could be used in support of
UK operations 54 watch keepers have cost
the army 850 million pounds and for the
first time their use has been approved
by the Civil Aviation Authority the
craft itself might be unmanned but
couldn't even get off the ground without
a team of five we've been constrained in
the past by not having something we
could utilize in the UK especially a
tactical level level with the ability to
have Watchkeeper and operate it from
Boscombe over-salty plane training area
then we can directly interact with those
wheat support in real life anyway drones
as they're more commonly known have been
used for years most notably in
Afghanistan some like the RAF Sri /
carry weapons that along with Americans
using similar craft to kill suspected
al-qaeda members has proved highly
controversial but the army insists this
is just for gathering intelligence the
Watchkeeper is certainly an impressive
piece of hardware with a 35 foot
wingspan it can fly in any conditions
day and night unlike all other army air
systems it'll be unarmed the British
Army does not operate any armed UAS and
there are no plans to arm Watchkeeper
system well at the moment that is an
area that we haven't explored so at the
moment there are no plans to arm
Watchkeeper flights will be restricted
by air traffic control but as this eye
in the sky now takes to the air many
will be watching with interest Ben Moore
BBC news
